**Central Secretariat Service** ([Hindi](/wiki/Hindi_language "Hindi
language"): केंद्रीय सचिवालय सेवा) (abbreviated as **CSS**) is the
[administrative](/wiki/Public_administration "Public administration") [civil
service](/wiki/Civil_Services_of_India "Civil Services of India") under Group
A[3] and Group B[4] of the [Central Civil
Services](/wiki/Central_Civil_Services_of_India "Central Civil Services of
India") of the [executive branch](/wiki/Executive_branch "Executive branch")
of the [Government of India](/wiki/Government_of_India "Government of India").
They are governed by Central Secretariat Service Rules of 1962,[5] which has
been issued under the powers of Article 309 of the [Constitution of
India](/wiki/Constitution_of_India "Constitution of India").[5]

The service serves as the backbone of administrative work[6][7] and provides
permanent bureaucracy and functionary staff in the Central [Government of
India](/wiki/Government_of_India "Government of India").

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_Secretariat_Service&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

In the year 1919, the [Imperial Secretariat
Service](/wiki/Imperial_Secretariat_Service "Imperial Secretariat Service")
came into being as one of the offshoots of the Lewllyn-Smith Committee which
had been set up on the eve of the introduction of the [Montagu–Chelmsford
Reforms](/wiki/Montagu%E2%80%93Chelmsford_Reforms "Montagu–Chelmsford
Reforms").[8] The posts of Assistant and Assistant Secretary/Under Secretary
were filled by officers drawn from the Imperial Secretariat Service during the
[British Raj](/wiki/British_Raj "British Raj").[9]

In 1946, after India gained [independence](/wiki/Partition_of_India "Partition
of India") from [Britain](/wiki/British_Raj "British Raj"), the Imperial
Secretariat Service was replaced by Central Secretariat Service in India.
However, in Pakistan, a Central Secretariat Service was formed in [Central
Superior Services of Pakistan](/wiki/Central_Superior_Services_of_Pakistan
"Central Superior Services of Pakistan"),[10] which was later replaced and
renamed to Office Management Group (OMG).[10]

Thus, the CSS became one of the earliest organized services[8] in
[India](/wiki/India "India").

##
Recruitment[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_Secretariat_Service&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Recruitment")]

From 1946 until 2003, 50 percent of direct recruitment into CSS[11] was
through the [Civil Services Examination](/wiki/Civil_Services_Examination
"Civil Services Examination") conducted by the [Union Public Service
Commission](/wiki/Union_Public_Service_Commission "Union Public Service
Commission"),[12] the next 25 percent recruitment was through Annual
Departmental Examination and next 25 percent by promotion.

However, after the cadre restructuring in 2003, the direct recruitment into
CSS through the [Civil Services Examination](/wiki/Civil_Services_Examination
"Civil Services Examination") has been stopped.

The mode of recruitment was changed to the grade of Section Officer by way of
50% through Limited Departmental Competitive Examination by [Union Public
Service Commission](/wiki/Union_Public_Service_Commission "Union Public
Service Commission")[13] and 50% by seniority.

## Allocation and
placement[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_Secretariat_Service&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Allocation and placement")]

After appointment by the [President](/wiki/President_of_India "President of
India"), the officers (Entry grade/Probationers) are allocated to different
Ministries/Departments under [Government of India](/wiki/Government_of_India
"Government of India"). The Group B officers work in the levels of Assistant
Section Officer and Section Officer/Assistant Director (For Directorate). The
Group A officers work in the levels of Under Secretary/Deputy Director (For
Directorate), Deputy Secretary/Joint Director (For Directorate), Director,
[Joint Secretary](/wiki/Joint_Secretary_to_Government_of_India "Joint
Secretary to Government of India")[14][15] and Additional Secretary[14][16]
under Central Staffing Scheme of [Government of
India](/wiki/Government_of_India "Government of India"). The officers are
generally posted in various Ministries and Departments, [intelligence
agencies](/wiki/List_of_Indian_intelligence_agencies "List of Indian
intelligence agencies"),[17] Apex /Autonomous organizations of Government of
India located at different places in the Secretariat in New Delhi. They are
also appointed in personal staff of [Union Council of Ministers of
India](/wiki/Union_Council_of_Ministers_of_India "Union Council of Ministers
of India").[18][19]

###
Deputations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_Secretariat_Service&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Deputations")]

The officers are also posted outside Delhi, or at various places of the
country in other offices upon deputation. They can also be deputed for service
under an international organization, an autonomous body not controlled by the
Government, or a private body as same as under Rule 6 (2)(ii) of
[IAS](/wiki/Indian_Administrative_Service "Indian Administrative Service")
(Cadre) Rules.[20]

In 2016, [Government of India](/wiki/Government_of_India "Government of
India") has approved officers to be posted on non-cadre posts in the
secretariat of [Northeastern states of India](/wiki/Northeast_India "Northeast
India").[21][22]

## Designations and Pay
grade[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_Secretariat_Service&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Designations and Pay grade")]

| Position / Pay Grade in the Government of India  | Level and Rank in the Central Government  | [Order of Precedence](/wiki/Indian_order_of_precedence "Indian order of precedence")   
(As per Presidential order)  | Equivalent Position or Designation in the State Government(s)   
---|---|---|---|---  
1  | Entry Grade  | **Assistant Section Officer** / Entry-level (Probationer) OR Promoted from the post of UDC**[23]** | \-  | Review Officer in State Secretariat   
2  | Junior Time Scale  | **Assistant Secretary / Section Officer** | \-  | Section Officer   
3  | Junior Time Scale (NFSG)  | **Assistant Secretary / Assistant Director (to the Directorate)** | \-  | Under Secretary/Sub-Divisional Magistrate   
4  | Senior Time Scale  | **Under Secretary** or Deputy Director (to the Directorate)  | \-  | Deputy Secretary/Additional District Magistrate   
5  | Junior Administrative Grade (JAG)  | **Deputy Secretary** or Joint Director (to the Directorate)  | \-  | Joint Secretary/District Magistrate   
6  | Selection Grade  | **Director** | \-  | Additional Secretary /Deputy Commissioner/Special Secretary   
7  | Super Time Scale  | **[Joint Secretary to Government of India](/wiki/Joint_Secretary_to_Government_of_India "Joint Secretary to Government of India")** | 26  | Secretary/Divisional Commissioner   
  
##
Reforms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_Secretariat_Service&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Reforms")]

### 1st Cadre Restructure of
2003[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_Secretariat_Service&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: 1st Cadre Restructure of 2003")]

In 2003, a committee was formed under the leadership of Additional Secretary
(GOI). The direct induction of CSS officer through [Civil Services
Examination](/wiki/Civil_Services_Examination "Civil Services Examination")
was permanently stopped. Also a new level G training program was organised for
those in line of promotion in the rank of Joint Secretary (GOI) in the SAG
level.[13]

### 2nd Cadre Restructure of
2010[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_Secretariat_Service&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: 2nd Cadre Restructure of 2010")]

The Government had set up a Committee on Cadre Restructuring of Central
Secretariat Service (CSS) in June 2008. The Committee submitted its report in
November 2008 for further reforms in the service. The report was finally
accepted in 2010 and the number of posts at various levels including Deputy
Secretaries and Directors were increased following the review [24]

### 3rd Cadre Restructure of
2013[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_Secretariat_Service&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: 3rd Cadre Restructure of 2013")]

A committee was formed under the leadership of Additional Secretary (GOI) in
2013 for further reforms in the service.[25] The report is currently pending
with [Prime Minister's Office](/wiki/Prime_Minister%27s_Office_\(India\)
"Prime Minister's Office \(India\)") and is expected to improve the service
conditions by increasing the number of posts at the level of Deputy
Secretaries.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Mandatory Training Program for CSS
Officers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_Secretariat_Service&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Mandatory Training Program for CSS Officers")]

In addition to these, the Government has also introduced mandatory training
programs at every level of promotion.[26] The CSS officers are trained both in
India and abroad[27] in various institutions starting at Level E
onwards.[28][29]

###
Controversies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_Secretariat_Service&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Controversies")]

Recently, some CSS officers have been in the list of corrupt bureaucrats and
have come under the CBI scanner for alleged involvement in a few corruption
cases.[30]

## Notable
members[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_Secretariat_Service&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Notable members")]

[![\[icon\]](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-
Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg)| This
section **needs expansion**. You can help by [adding to
it](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Central_Secretariat_Service&action=edit&section=).
_(July 2016)_  
---|---  
  
Since its inception, CSS has produced few outstanding civil servants in
India.[31] Influential members include - M.P. Singh[32] who was appointed as
Vice-Chairman of Central Administrative Tribunal at Jabalpur Bench,[32] P.G.
Lele who served as Additional Secretary to Government of India[33] in the
[Ministry of Finance](/wiki/Ministry_of_Finance_\(India\) "Ministry of Finance
\(India\)") and M.V. Ayyar who was empanelled as [Secretary to Government of
India](/wiki/Secretary_to_Government_of_India "Secretary to Government of
India").

Reportedly, in the 1960s, there have been Labour Secretary and Education
Secretary in Government of India also from CSS.

##
Influence[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Central_Secretariat_Service&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Influence")]

The Railway Board Secretariat Service, the general administration staff in the
[Ministry of Railways](/wiki/Ministry_of_Railways_\(India\) "Ministry of
Railways \(India\)"), is modelled after the Central Secretariat Service.[34]
